awd_titl_txt: Hydroclimate Variability and the Evolution of Socioecological Complexity in Dryland Farming Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the ecological constraints on the evolution of social complexity in dryland ecosystems remains a major challenge in archaeological research. Most global case studies of foraging-farming transitions in drylands lack the requisite chronological precision and fine-grained environmental information necessary to reconstruct the subtle interactions between environment and society during these important moments of subsistence change, population growth, and social development. Early societies in western North America provide a rare example of the ephemeral adoption of agriculture and development of social complexity. Imprecise chronologies for relevant horticultural villages and their immediate hydroclimatic contexts have led to a lack of consensus on the development of social complexity. This project tests two hypotheses about the formation of such villages: the largest and most socially complex villages had the longest occupation spans; and the longest occupied villages occurred in river basins that are least sensitive to hydroclimate variability regimes. The project provides research sites for participants in the Utah State University Native American Summer Mentorship Program, a focused research experience for native students that encourages transfer and successful degree completion. The PIs collaborate with faculty and students at the Eastern Prehistoric Museum and Anthropology Museum to develop a traveling exhibit of the project findings that will be hosted at four public museums throughout the state for three months each. A three-part lecture series accompanies the exhibit where each project investigator presents the results of their individual studies. 

The research team will develop tree-ring-based reconstructions of local stream discharge for the last two millenia, build and test a basin sensitivity model connecting local hydroclimate and geomorphic variables, and evaluate village longevity, size and complexity using high-density, high-precision chronological models. Communities that developed under conditions where vulnerability thresholds were crossed with less frequency should have longer occupational durations, larger sizes, and more evidence of complexity. This project provides a comparative framework explaining the fundamental processes of agricultural community formation and stability that enabled the growth of populations and social complexity in dryland ecosystems. The project systematically combines dendrochronology, geoarchaeology, and high-precision archaeological radiocarbon dating to resolve time at the multidecadal/multigenerational scales necessary to capture the dynamic social-ecological processes constraining the stability, size, and development of social complexity in early agricultural societies. The project findings are a key case study in the global comparative analyses of the sustainability of past and modern dryland agricultural societies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project examined the social and ecological conditions under which farming communities emerged in western North America. Maize agriculture was practiced in Utah north of the Colorado River between AD 300–1300. This is one of the latest known agricultural transitions making it an important point of global comparison. Utah was and is a challenging environment for farmers because unpredictable precipitation and temperatures make agriculture risky. Yet the archaeological record demonstrates that farming was successful as many early communities developed regionally. Unknown prior to our research was when these communities formed, how long they persisted, and what were the specific environmental conditions that influenced their persistence and socioeconomic potential. Understanding these dynamics in a series of case studies was the purpose of our study.

Our project area is one of great ecological contrasts. The northern Colorado Plateau is characterized by massive slickrock landforms that direct surface runoff onto the floodplains of deeply entrenched canyons. The eastern Great Basin is dominated by steep mountains with broad alluvial fans that form where streams emerge onto valley floors. Northern Colorado Plateau floodplains and eastern Great Basin alluvial fans were the largest available agricultural niches for Indigenous farmers, but canyon floodplains are inherently less geologically stable than alluvial fans. Thus, our working hypothesis suggested early villages that developed in more stable geological environments have the potential to persist longer, grow larger, and develop greater forms of social complexity.

Previous research suggested that early farming communities formed quickly under favorable environmental conditions but were abandoned when that changed. We demonstrated the chronological and paleoecological requirements to understand these social-ecological dynamics, yet the existing data were insufficient to test our working hypothesis. Furthermore, no geoarchaeological studies bridged site occupation histories with environmental reconstructions. Thus, we proposed three separate work packages: 1) high-precision archaeological dating of six regionally representative agricultural villages; 2) an expanded network of precipitation and streamflow reconstructions, and 3) site-specific geoarchaeological studies that examine the relative stability of local landforms associated with the selected villages.

We developed three datasets that directly address our working hypothesis. We produced 290 new AMS radiocarbon ages based on maize, seeds, and basketry/textile fibers from six sites. We constructed 15 new tree-ring chronologies from sites that form an important latitudinal cross-section of Utah. The tree-ring chronologies are strongly correlated providing annually resolved records spanning 3,200 years. We confidently modeled precipitation and streamflow for the last 1,200 years. Finally, we reconstructed the geomorphic history for three of five study sites. These are exceptional datasets that will serve archaeologists and paleoecologists for decades.

Our data directly test the hypothesis that larger and more complex communities developed in stable geological environments and had longer occupations. There are two key results from our AMS dating: 1) nearly all villages had short occupation spans of 60–80 years, and 2) there is a clear north-south historical trajectory of village development. Precipitation and streamflow were regionally stable leading up to the development of nearly all our study sites. Disruptive hydrological events are those where discharge exceeded the 99th percentile of all years compared to the historic average. High-discharge events can result in massive erosion of canyon floodplains, a key expectation of our working hypothesis. Such events were more common across the Colorado Plateau beginning in the late AD 1000s and continuing through the late AD 1200s. Some high-discharge events correspond to village abandonment.

While geomorphic instability can be implicated as a fundamental limit on the growth of some early agricultural communities, it does not explain the growth limits for all communities. For example, Snake Rock Village persisted for >200 years and the local floodplain was in a constant phase of sedimentation indicating a relatively stable floodplain in otherwise unstable Colorado Plateau geomorphic systems. Finally, the largest and most complex site in our study, Five Finger Ridge, was the last to develop between AD 1110–1180 and was apparently selected for its stable and productive geomorphic environment on the edge of two massive alluvial fans. Clear Creek discharge rarely exceeded the 99th percentile, and the landscape was geomorphically stable. The Five Finger Ridge findings suggest a new working hypothesis that social variables, possibly conflict within and between communities, was a more important constraint to early agricultural villages than ecological variables.

We consider our results to be a remarkable success. We produced robust archaeological, paleoecological, and geoarchaeological datasets that serve researchers across disciplines. While some elements of our working hypothesis were supported, we developed new working hypotheses that can be tested with additional data. Finally, our results directly place the history of early agricultural villages in our study area directly in context with the Ancestral Pueblo world of the greater American Southwest, which is characterized by cycles of growth and movement typical of our Utah study area.
